title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome! This is Nico TestingW!!!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Post With Code
text: This is a post with executable code.

title: Bruin
text:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 2, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()

title: HW 0
text:
Import all necessary packages, and import the Palmer Penguins data set. For this assignment, we use the pandas package and the matplotlib.pyplot package.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
df = pd.read_csv(url)

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
df = pd.read_csv(url)

title: HW 0
text:
Step 3: Breaking up the data
We see in the data there are three types of penguins: Adelie, Gentoo, and Chinstrap. We also see there’s data on each penguins flipper length and body mass.
We can build a scatterplot to see the relationship between the penguin’s flipper lenght and body mass. We can take this one step further and split this scatterplot up into the three types of penguins.
Let’s start by breaking up the data frame into three smaller data frames. Each data frame will take all the entries pretaining to an individual species of penguin. Therefore, we will have 3 new data frames (since there are three species of penguins).

# breaking up the data to be with certain species
adelie = df[df["Species"] == "Adelie Penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae)"]
gentoo = df[df["Species"] == "Gentoo penguin (Pygoscelis papua)"]
chinstrap = df[df["Species"] == "Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica)"]

Now, we can preview the new data frame pretaining to the Adelie species.

title: HW 0
text:
Step 4: Building the Scatterplot
Now that we have our individual data frames, we can build our scatterplot using the plt.scatter command. We will index the data within the columns “Body Mass (g)” and “Flipper Length (mm)” for our x and y axis. We will color code each speciesof penguin as well.
We can also add x and y axis labels, a plot title, and a legend.

plt.scatter(adelie['Body Mass (g)'], adelie['Flipper Length (mm)'], marker='o', linestyle='', color='b', label='Adelie Penguin')
plt.scatter(gentoo['Body Mass (g)'], gentoo['Flipper Length (mm)'], marker='o', linestyle='', color='red', label='Gentoo Penguin')
plt.scatter(chinstrap['Body Mass (g)'], chinstrap['Flipper Length (mm)'], marker='o', linestyle='', color='green', label='Chinstrap Penguin')


plt.xlabel('Body Mass (grams)')
plt.ylabel('Flipper Length (mm)')
plt.title('Plotting Flipper Length vs Body Mass')


plt.legend()
